questions.text: A 2900-g (6.4-lb) male newborn is delivered at term to a 29-year-old primigravid woman. His mother had no routine prenatal care. She reports that the pregnancy was uncomplicated apart from a 2-week episode of a low-grade fever and swollen lymph nodes during her early pregnancy. She has avoided all routine vaccinations because she believes that “natural immunity is better”. The newborn is at the 35th percentile for height, 15th percentile for weight, and 90th percentile for head circumference. Fundoscopic examination shows inflammation of the choroid and the retina in both eyes. A CT scan of the head shows diffuse intracranial calcifications and mild ventriculomegaly. Prenatal avoidance of which of the following would have most likely prevented this newborn's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Exposure of an unvaccinated pregnant woman to unvaccinated children is a risk factor for maternal infection with exanthematous diseases of childhood, such as rubella and varicella. Congenital rubella syndrome typically manifests with cardiac defects, cataracts, and cochlear defects (Gregg triad). Although chorioretinitis and ventriculomegaly can be seen in congenital varicella infection, further symptoms, such as hypertrophic scars and limb hypoplasia, would also be expected. Moreover, the mother has not reported a rash characteristic of either disease.

B) CORRECT:

In the US, consumption of contaminated, undercooked meat is the most common cause of Toxoplasma gondii infection during pregnancy. While the likelihood of transplacental transmission is low in early pregnancy, the risk of symptomatic toxoplasmosis in the newborn is highest if infection occurs in the first trimester. Maternal toxoplasmosis is usually asymptomatic but may manifest with general symptoms, such as low-grade fever and cervical lymphadenopathy. Other sources of maternal infection include accidental ingestion of contaminated cat feces and drinking unpasteurized goat's milk.
Image Description:

The life cycle of toxoplasmosis involves transmission to a human host through the ingestion of cat feces particulate that contains oocysts or ingestion of meat (i.e., pork) containing Toxoplasma cysts. Cross-placental transmission is possible after the initial infection of pregnant women.

C) INCORRECT:

Unprotected sexual intercourse during pregnancy is a risk factor for sexually transmitted diseases (e.g., HIV, CMV, HSV-2, syphilis), which may lead to congenital infections. This newborn presents with chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications, and ventriculomegaly, all of which are consistent with congenital CMV infection. Moreover, the mother's symptoms during early pregnancy (low-grade fever, cervical lymphadenopathy) are a possible manifestation of CMV mononucleosis. However, intracranial calcifications are usually limited to the periventricular region in congenital CMV infection unlike the diffuse pattern seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Infection with the Zika virus (e.g., through mosquito bites) during pregnancy can lead to congenital birth defects, such as ventriculomegaly and intracranial calcifications. However, congenital Zika infection is not associated with chorioretinitis. Moreover, the mother has not reported typical symptoms of Zika infection, such as a pruritic maculopapular rash or arthralgia, nor did she travel to an endemic region.

E) INCORRECT:

Consumption of raw cow milk products during pregnancy is a risk factor for Listeria monocytogenes infection, which may lead to granulomatosis infantiseptica in newborns. This condition is characterized by respiratory distress and skin lesions. Although the mother's nonspecific febrile illness in early pregnancy could have been a manifestation of listeriosis, her child's symptoms suggest congenital toxoplasmosis. Toxoplasma gondii infection has been associated with the ingestion of contaminated raw goat milk rather than cow milk products.
questions.hint: Chorioretinitis, diffuse intracranial calcifications, and hydrocephalus (indicated by ventriculomegaly) in a newborn are characteristic of congenital toxoplasmosis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old gravida 2, para 1 comes to the physician because she has had an itchy rash all over her body for the past 3 days. It started on her face and gradually progressed downwards. She reports painless swelling of her knee joints and denies trauma. She had flu-like symptoms 3–4 days prior to the appearance of the rash. She has received no prenatal care. She delivered her first child vaginally without complications. She takes an iron supplement; her immunization records are unavailable. Examination shows a pink maculopapular rash over her body sparing her palms and soles. Postauricular lymphadenopathy is present. Knee joints are mildly swollen and range of motion is normal. Examination shows a uterus consistent with a 24-week gestation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used in the treatment of chickenpox (varicella zoster), which may cause congenital varicella syndrome. Chickenpox manifests with an itchy rash and a flu-like prodrome. This patient has a maculopapular rash instead of a vesiculopustular rash at different stages at once, the latter being typical for chickenpox. Additionally, the rash in chickenpox starts on the trunk, not on the face.

B) INCORRECT:

Counseling about the potentially devastating effects on the fetus and the possibility of terminating the pregnancy is indicated if maternal rubella infection occurs during the first trimester. The risk of congenital rubella syndrome is extremely low (< 1%) if fetal rubella infection occurs after 16 weeks of gestation. Given the incubation period of rubella infection (2–3 weeks) and the fact that clinical features of maternal rubella infection occurred at 24 weeks of gestation, it is safe to assume that this patient could have, at worst, acquired the infection at 21 weeks of gestation. Termination of pregnancy is therefore not recommended in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The rubella vaccine (MMR vaccine) is a live vaccine and is, therefore, contraindicated during pregnancy. Furthermore, vaccination would not be helpful for this patient who already has the condition. The MMR vaccine should, however, be administered to all nonpregnant women of childbearing age who have an unknown vaccination history or are seronegative for rubella-specific IgG.

D) CORRECT:

Rubella infection in a pregnant woman can put the fetus at risk of developing congenital rubella syndrome, especially during the first trimester. After the 16th week of gestation, however, the risk of developing congenital defects is very low; reassurance and symptomatic therapy (e.g., acetaminophen) are usually recommended. If rubella infection occurred before 16 weeks of gestation, the patient should be counseled about the potentially devastating effects on the fetus and the possibility of terminating the pregnancy.

E) INCORRECT:

If a pregnant woman is exposed to a patient with rubella, passive immunization with intravenous immunoglobulins (IVIG) within 5 days of exposure can prevent maternal rubella infection. However, routine administration of IVIG is not recommended if rubella infection has already become symptomatic. In addition, while it may reduce maternal symptoms, IVIG does not prevent congenital rubella syndrome. As this patient has mild symptoms and is already in the 24th week of her pregnancy, this intervention is not indicated.
questions.hint: An itchy maculopapular rash that started on the face and spread to the rest of the body but spares the palms and soles, in combination with postauricular lymphadenopathy and polyarthritis, is highly suggestive of rubella.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 9 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for her first prenatal visit. She has had some mild nausea but is otherwise feeling well. Her first pregnancy was uneventful. Her son was born at 40 weeks' gestation via cesarean delivery because of a nonreassuring fetal status.  Her current medications include prenatal vitamins with folic acid. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Preconception rubella and varicella titers were recorded as adequate. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 114/65 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 9-week gestation. A complete blood cell count is within normal limits. At the end of the visit, the woman says she has been concerned about her son. He is now 16 months old and has had a low-grade fever for 5 days. He also has a generalized rash that started on his cheeks 2 days ago and has since spread to his body. The patient wonders if her son's disease is contagious. A photograph of the son is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Isolation precautions for the child and report the disease to health authorities
PCR for viral DNA in amniotic fluid
Maternal serologic assays for virus-specific IgG and IgM

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Once the rash of parvovirus B19 infection has appeared, the infected individual is no longer contagious. Exposure of this pregnant woman has therefore already occurred and isolation precautions would be of no benefit. In addition, while the list of reportable diseases includes many diseases, including measles and rubella, parvovirus B19 infection is not reportable.

B) INCORRECT:

Reassurance is only appropriate in pregnant women exposed to parvovirus B19 if they have immunity to the pathogen. Another step in management is appropriate first.

C) INCORRECT:

PCR is a sensitive method to test for parvovirus B19 DNA in amniotic fluid and diagnose fetal parvovirus infection, and it is instrumental in determining the cause of fetal hydrops. Although this pregnant patient was exposed to parvovirus B19, she may not be infected, and the risk of fetal transmission is therefore unknown. This invasive procedure is not indicated at this time; another step in management is more appropriate.

D) CORRECT:

All pregnant individuals exposed to parvovirus B19 should undergo serologic assays for IgG and IgM to determine infection status and risk of fetal complications. Although the likelihood of developing parvovirus-induced congenital anomalies (e.g., severe anemia, fetal hydrops) is negligible if infection occurs before 20 weeks' gestation, pregnant patients with acute infection should still be counseled on the risk of fetal loss. In pregnant patients with acute parvovirus B19 infection after 20 weeks' gestation, periodic fetal ultrasounds (every 1–2 weeks) are indicated to screen for fetal hydrops. Pregnant women with immunity to parvovirus B19 can be reassured as there is no risk of fetal complications from this pathogen. See “Serologic assay analysis for parvovirus B19” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immunoglobulins (IVIGs) are mainly used to treat chronic parvovirus B19 infection in immunocompromised individuals with anemia. This patient is not immunocompromised. Furthermore, it is not yet clear if she is infected with or has immunity against parvovirus B19.

F) INCORRECT:

Periodic fetal ultrasounds (every 1–2 weeks) are indicated in pregnant patients infected with parvovirus B19 after 20 weeks' gestation to screen for fetal hydrops. Although this patient was exposed to parvovirus B19, she may not be infected. Moreover, the risk of developing congenital anomalies (e.g., fetal hydrops) from parvovirus B19 is negligible if infection occurs before 20 weeks' gestation. Therefore, serial ultrasounds are not indicated.
questions.hint: The boy presents with a flulike illness followed by a diffuse red confluent maculopapular facial rash with a slapped cheek appearance that has spread to his body. These clinical features were likely caused by infection with parvovirus B19.

questions.text:
A 5-day-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after having a seizure. It lasted approximately 1 minute, and involved blinking and lip-smacking movements as well as left-sided jerking of the hand and foot. His mother says she measured a temperature of 38.2°C (100.7°F) at that time. He has had increasing difficulty feeding since yesterday. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation and weighed 3189 g (7 lb 1 oz); he currently weighs 2980 g (6 lb 9 oz). The mother's prenatal course was significant for gonorrhea infection diagnosed early in pregnancy and treated with ceftriaxone and azithromycin combination therapy. The boy appears irritable and lethargic. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F). Examination shows clusters of vesicular lesions with an erythematous base on the patient's face and trunk. There is profuse lacrimation. Laboratory studies show:


Leukocyte count
16,200/mm3



Segmented neutrophils
25%


Bands
5%


Lymphocytes
65%


Monocytes
3%


Eosinophils
2%


Serum



Glucose
80 mg/dL


A lumbar puncture is performed. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a leukocyte count of 117/μL, a protein concentration of 52 mg/dL, and a glucose concentration of 58 mg/dL. Results of blood cultures are pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ganciclovir is indicated for congenital cytomegalovirus infection, which may manifest with seizures. However, this condition also classically manifests with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, microcephaly, and, at later stages of development, sensorineural hearing loss. Furthermore, congenital cytomegalovirus infection does not manifest with a vesicular rash.

B) INCORRECT:

Ampicillin is a first-line treatment for group B Streptococcus (GBS), which is the most common cause of neonatal meningitis. While this patient likely has a CNS infection, his laboratory analysis suggests a nonbacterial cause (normal CSF glucose, ↑ lymphocyte count). Bacterial meningitis typically manifests on CSF analysis with low glucose, high protein, and high neutrophil count. Moreover, this patient's vesicular rash is not commonly associated with GBS.

C) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is indicated in the treatment of neonatal gonococcal infection (Neisseria gonorrhoeae). Although perinatal gonococcal infection in this patient is possible given his mother's history, she had already been treated at the time of his birth, making transmission unlikely. Moreover, neonatal gonococcal infection is associated with prematurity and purulent conjunctivitis, not CNS infection or vesicular rash.

D) CORRECT:

Acyclovir therapy should be initiated as soon as neonatal HSV is suspected, as the condition is rapidly progressive and can have severe sequelae (such as disseminated disease or this patient's likely meningoencephalitis). Neonatal HSV infection should be suspected in infants up to 6 weeks of age that present with vesicular skin lesions, especially if features of meningitis/encephalitis and/or sepsis (e.g., seizures, lethargy, and persistent fever) are present.

The prognosis of neonatal HSV depends on the extent of organ involvement. In infants with CNS involvement, only 30% will go on to have normal neurologic development.

E) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin is a first-line treatment for neonatal meningitis caused by coagulase-negative staphylococci (e.g., S. epidermidis), which can cause meningitis in neonates with very low birth weight (< 1500 g) or those who underwent CNS surgery (e.g., placement of a ventriculoperitoneal shunt). While this patient likely has a CNS infection, his laboratory analysis suggests a nonbacterial cause (normal CSF glucose, ↑ lymphocyte count). Bacterial meningitis typically manifests on CSF analysis with low glucose, high protein, and high neutrophil count. Moreover, this patient's vesicular rash is not associated with staphylococcal meningitis, his birth weight is normal, and he has no history of CNS surgery.

F) INCORRECT:

The combination of gentamicin and ampicillin works synergistically to increase the bactericidal effect of treatment and is used to treat neonatal Listeria monocytogenes infection, which is the third most common cause of neonatal meningitis. While this patient likely has a CNS infection, his laboratory analysis suggests a nonbacterial cause (normal CSF glucose, ↑ lymphocyte count). Bacterial meningitis typically manifests on CSF analysis with low glucose, high protein, and high neutrophil count. Moreover, this patient's vesicular rash is not commonly associated with listeriosis.
questions.hint: A seizure accompanied by fever is strongly concerning for neonatal meningitis and/or encephalitis. A high CSF protein and normal CSF glucose (∼ ⅔ of blood glucose) suggest a viral CNS infection. His diffuse vesicular rash suggests neonatal herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 39 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She has some mild edema and tiredness but generally feels well. Her nephew visited for 1 week and left 3 days ago because he became ill and was diagnosed with chickenpox. She has no history of chickenpox and is not vaccinated against the varicella zoster virus. Current medications include folic acid supplements and a prenatal vitamin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 116/64 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with 39 weeks' gestation. IgG antibody titers for the varicella zoster virus are negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The varicella vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine, which is contraindicated during pregnancy due to the risk of the fetus becoming infected. Seronegative women of child-bearing age should receive a varicella vaccine before becoming pregnant.

B) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir may be recommended for pregnant women with an active varicella infection in the second or third trimester. This medication is also administered to newborns with severe neonatal varicella infection. Although this patient has been exposed to VZV and is at high risk of developing chickenpox, she does not have an active infection at this time. Acyclovir plays no role in the prevention of chickenpox.

Prescription of acyclovir for pregnant women must be done with caution as there are no well-controlled studies about its use during pregnancy (category B).

C) INCORRECT:

Serial ultrasounds are indicated for a pregnant woman who has chickenpox in the first or second trimester since the fetus is at risk of developing congenital varicella syndrome, which can lead to CNS, ocular, and limb defects. However, the patient here is at 39 weeks' gestation and is only at risk of developing chickenpox; therefore, no serial ultrasounds are indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

This woman is at high risk of developing chickenpox and its complications (e.g., pneumonia, encephalitis), and her fetus is at increased risk of developing neonatal varicella infection. Counseling about the risks of varicella infection in the mother and fetus is necessary. Moreover, this patient requires additional treatment to prevent varicella infection or decrease its severity.

E) INCORRECT:

Ganciclovir is an antiviral medication effective against cytomegalovirus infections. This medication is not routinely used in varicella infections and plays no role in the prevention of chickenpox. In addition, the use of ganciclovir during pregnancy can pose risks to the fetus (category C), as animal studies have shown teratogenic effects.

F) CORRECT:

This pregnant woman is at an increased risk of developing varicella and its complications (e.g., encephalitis, pneumonia) because she does not have immunity against VZV. Passive immunization with varicella zoster immune globulin (VZIG) should be recommended in order to prevent infection or lessen its severity. VZIG is ideally given within 72–96 hours of exposure but can also be given as late as 10 days after exposure. Administration of VZIG can prevent fetal VZV infection. Neonatal varicella can manifest as a pox-like rash with potential visceral involvement in the form of pneumonia, encephalitis, or bacterial superinfection of the rash.
questions.hint: Transmission of the varicella zoster virus (VZV) late in pregnancy may result in neonatal varicella infection. The patient is also at risk for severe varicella infection herself and requires treatment to prevent complications.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 39 weeks' gestation, is admitted to the hospital in labor. She currently has contractions occurring every 3–5 minutes. For the past 3 days, she has had burning pain in the vulvar area associated with intense itching. Her pregnancy has been uneventful. She has a history of genital herpes at the age of 16, which was treated with acyclovir. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Genital examination shows grouped vesicles on an erythematous base over the vulvar region. Pelvic examination shows rupture of membranes and that the cervix is 3 cm dilated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Tocolytic therapy until lesions are crusted
Oral acyclovir therapy and vaginal delivery
Oral acyclovir therapy and cesarean delivery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Suppressing labor via tocolytics would not be a practical solution to preventing vertical transmission. Herpetic lesions take 10–12 days to crust and tocolytic agents are generally not recommended for more than 48 hours (although some may be effective for several more days). Additionally, the virus may still be present in maternal secretions even after initial crusting.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical acyclovir is less effective than oral acyclovir at reducing the symptoms of genital herpes. Although oral acyclovir therapy reduces the severity of symptoms and the duration of viral shedding, it does not prevent transmission to the newborn in patients with active genital herpes, which is why cesarean delivery is indeed recommended to prevent neonatal herpes.

C) INCORRECT:

Although acyclovir therapy reduces the severity of symptoms and the duration of viral shedding, it does not prevent transmission to the newborn in patients with active genital herpes. Additionally, vaginal delivery would expose the newborn to HSV in maternal secretions and increase the risk of neonatal HSV infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical acyclovir is less effective than oral acyclovir at reducing the symptoms of genital herpes. Although oral acyclovir therapy reduces the severity of symptoms and the duration of viral shedding, it does not prevent transmission to the newborn in patients with active genital herpes. Additionally, vaginal delivery would expose the newborn to HSV in maternal secretions and increase the risk of neonatal HSV infection.

E) CORRECT:

The risk for vertical transmission to the neonate from an infected mother is high (up to 50%) among women who exhibit active genital herpes near the time of delivery. Cesarean delivery is indicated in women with recurrent and active genital herpes at the onset of labor to reduce the risk of transmission and thereby prevent neonatal HSV, which could result in severe complications like disseminated disease or meningoencephalitis. Although oral acyclovir does not prevent vertical transmission, it will help reduce the severity and duration of symptoms. In severe infection, IV acyclovir should be considered. If HSV lesions are not genital, delivery can proceed as normal. After birth, breastfeeding can also continue as usual unless lesions are on the breast.

Oral acyclovir can be used as suppressive therapy for genital herpes after 36 weeks' gestation until delivery in women with a prior history of genital herpes.

F) INCORRECT:

Active genital herpes during vaginal delivery increases the risk of vertical transmission, as it exposes the newborn to HSV in the maternal secretions, which can result in neonatal HSV and life-threatening complications.
questions.hint: The grouped vesicles in the vulvar region on an erythematous base indicate active genital herpes. The patient is in labor, as she is having contractions and her cervix is dilated 3 cm. What will prevent the newborn from acquiring a herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection?

questions.text: A 2-day-old male newborn delivered vaginally at 36 weeks to a 29-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 3, has generalized convulsions lasting 2 minutes. Previous to the event, he had difficulty feeding and was lethargic. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Pregnancy and delivery of the mother's first two children were also uncomplicated. Medications of the mother include folic acid and a multivitamin. The mother's immunizations are up-to-date. The infant appears icteric. His vital signs are within normal limits. The infant's weight and length are at the 5th percentile, and his head circumference is at the 99th percentile for gestational age. Physical examination shows a purpuric rash. Ocular examination shows posterior uveitis. Cranial ultrasonography shows ventricular dilatation, as well as diffuse hyperechoic foci within the cortex, basal ganglia, and periventricular region. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This newborn presents with chorioretinitis, diffuse intracranial calcifications, and signs of hydrocephalus (enlarged head circumference, ventriculomegaly), which indicate congenital toxoplasmosis. The diagnosis is further supported by the presence of purpuric rash, jaundice, and seizures. Congenital toxoplasmosis is treated with pyrimethamine, sulfadiazine, and leucovorin rescue for 1 year. Sequelae of congenital toxoplasmosis include epilepsy, intellectual disability, visual impairment (e.g., chorioretinitis), and sensorineural hearing loss.

See “Overview of congenital TORCH infections” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Although this newborn presents with low birth weight, purpuric rash (blueberry muffin rash), jaundice, and chorioretinitis, which are consistent with congenital rubella infection, his mother's immunizations are up to date, making an intrauterine infection unlikely. Additionally, the classic triad of congenital rubella infection consists of cardiac defects (e.g., patent ductus arteriosus), sensorineural hearing loss, and cataracts, none of which are present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Premature delivery, low birth weight, seizures, jaundice, chorioretinitis, purpuric rash, and ventriculomegaly can manifest in congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. While intracranial calcifications may occur in congenital CMV infection, they are usually limited to the periventricular region. In contrast, this patient's cranial ultrasonography shows diffuse calcifications involving the cortical, subcortical, and periventricular areas. Moreover, congenital CMV infection is usually associated with microcephaly and not macrocephaly.

D) INCORRECT:

Congenital syphilis may result in premature delivery, low birth weight, neonatal jaundice, and chorioretinitis. Although this condition can cause seizures, they do not manifest in newborns. Furthermore, this patient presents with intracranial calcifications and hydrocephalus, which are not associated with congenital syphilis.

E) INCORRECT:

Symptomatic congenital parvovirus infection manifests with severe aplastic anemia, fetal hydrops, and/or a high-output cardiac failure, which is inconsistent with this neonate's presentation.

F) INCORRECT:

A congenital varicella infection could explain this patient's low birth weight, chorioretinitis, and seizures. However, the mother's vaccinations are up-to-date, meaning intrauterine infection is very unlikely. Additionally, dermatomal hypertrophic scars would be expected, which are present in ∼ 80% of cases.
questions.hint: Diffuse intracranial calcifications (hyperechoic lesions on ultrasonography) are most specific to this congenital infection.

questions.text: A 3175-g (7-lb) female newborn is delivered at 37 weeks to a 26-year-old primigravid woman. Apgar scores are 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The pregnancy had been uncomplicated. The mother had no prenatal care. She immigrated to the US from Brazil 2 years ago. Immunization records are not available. One day after delivery, the newborn's temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 182/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 82/60 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a continuous heart murmur. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There are several discolored areas on the skin that are nonblanchable upon pressure application. Slit lamp examination shows cloudy lenses in both eyes. The newborn does not pass her auditory screening tests. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Findings of congenital varicella infections vary greatly, depending on what stage of pregnancy the maternal infection occurred. Classically, congenital varicella infection manifests with chorioretinitis, cataracts, hypertrophic scar tissue, limb malformations (e.g., hypoplasia), and CNS defects. While this patient's cataracts can be explained by a congenital varicella infection, it would not account for the newborn's heart murmur. This newborn is not described as having any limb abnormalities or hypertrophic scar tissue, which are usually seen in this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Congenital parvovirus B19 infections may cause fetal hydrops and aplastic anemia, which can result in miscarriage. This newborn may have anemia, but she does not display signs of hydrops such as edema of the subcutaneous tissue or scalp, ascites, or pleural effusions. Also, a congenital parvovirus B19 infection does not explain this patient's cataracts, auditory defect, or continuous heart murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

While congenital syphilis may cause sensorineural hearing loss, this is typically a late finding that does not occur until children have reached 8–10 years of age. Findings of early congenital syphilis (onset prior to 2 years of age) include rhinorrhea with white or bloody nasal discharge, a maculopapular rash on palms and soles, skeletal abnormalities (e.g., metaphyseal dystrophy, periostitis), and nontender generalized lymphadenopathy.

D) CORRECT:

The classic triad of congenital rubella infection is bilateral cataracts, sensorineural hearing loss (secondary to a cochlear dysfunction), and a heart defect – typically patent ductus arteriosus or pulmonary artery stenosis. Other, less specific findings include petechiae and purpura (“blueberry muffin rash”). Congenital rubella syndrome usually only results if the infection occurs during organogenesis, i.e., during the first 1–8 weeks of gestation. If the transmission occurs after 16 weeks' gestation, the risk of developing congenital rubella syndrome is extremely low.

There are different laboratory studies available to confirm the diagnosis of congenital rubella infection: PCR for rubella RNA, viral culture (both tests may be performed from nasal, throat, or blood specimens from the newborn), or serology (rubella-specific IgM or IgG antibodies in abnormally high or persistent concentrations).

E) INCORRECT:

Newborns with congenital toxoplasmosis typically present with chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications, and hydrocephalus. Cataracts and a heart murmur are not typical features of intrauterine infection with toxoplasmosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections typically manifest with sensorineural hearing loss, chorioretinitis, periventricular calcifications, and microcephaly. A congenital CMV infection may explain this patient's auditory defect, but it does not account for the newborn's bilateral cataracts or the heart murmur.
questions.hint: The mother of this newborn most likely did not receive the appropriate vaccinations, which put her and her child at risk of having contracted an infectious disease during the pregnancy. The newborn now presents with cataracts, auditory defects, and a murmur suggestive of patent ductus arteriosus, which is a triad of symptoms characteristic of a particular congenital infection (sometimes referred to as Gregg triad).

questions.text: A 1710-g (3.77-lb) male newborn is delivered to a 27-year-old woman at 33 weeks' gestation. Pregnancy was uncomplicated, but the mother had a cold and sore throat 2 months before delivery that resolved spontaneously. The newborn appears lethargic. He is at the 15th percentile for height and weight and at the 1st percentile for head circumference. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is jaundice of the skin and conjunctivae. Abdominal examination shows hepatosplenomegaly. A cranial ultrasound of the newborn shows periventricular calcifications. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Crigler-Najjar syndrome can cause severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which can subsequently lead to icterus and lethargy. However, patients with Crigler-Najjar syndrome appear developmentally normal and would not present with microcephaly or intracranial calcifications.

B) INCORRECT:

Cri-du-chat syndrome can cause microcephaly and growth retardation. However, it also causes other facial dysmorphisms, such as ear malformations, hypertelorism, and downslanting palpebral fissures, which are not present in this patient. In addition, cri-du-chat syndrome would not explain this patient's hepatosplenomegaly, scleral icterus, or periventricular calcifications.

C) INCORRECT:

Congenital Zika virus infection can cause growth retardation, microcephaly, and intracranial calcifications but infection by the Zika virus is more common in tropical or subtropical regions (e.g., South America, Pacific Islands, Puerto Rico). This patient has no history of travel to an endemic region. In addition, the intracranial calcifications in congenital Zika syndrome are typically located at the junction of gray and white matter unlike the periventricular calcifications that are seen here, and other characteristic features of congenital Zika virus infection such as hypertonia and joint contractures have not been reported in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) can lead to the triad of facial dysmorphism (including microcephaly), growth retardation, and CNS dysfunction. Rarely, it can also cause neonatal jaundice and hepatomegaly. However, this child's facial dysmorphism (isolated microcephaly) is inconsistent with the facial dysmorphism characteristic of FAS (thin upper lip, smooth philtrum, and short palpebral fissures). In addition, FAS would not explain this child's intracranial calcifications.

E) INCORRECT:

Congenital toxoplasmosis can also manifest with neonatal jaundice, microcephaly, and hepatosplenomegaly. However, other typical features of congenital toxoplasmosis include hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, and diffuse intracranial calcifications (rather than localized periventricular calcifications).

F) CORRECT:

This neonate's low birth weight, jaundice, microcephaly, and periventricular calcifications are all findings associated with congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. Congenital CMV infection is the most common congenital infection and occurs in approx. 1% of live births in the US, although only 10% of these neonates are symptomatic. Other characteristic symptoms include chorioretinitis, sensorineural hearing loss, petechiae, and purpura (blueberry muffin rash). The risk of CMV transmission increases throughout pregnancy, whereas the risk of congenital defects is highest if the fetus is infected in the first trimester. The majority of maternal CMV infections are asymptomatic. This mother's history of a cold and sore throat 2 months prior to delivery are less likely to be related to this neonate's CMV infection.
questions.hint: Hearing screening in infants with this condition often reveals sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She reports feeling fatigue and having swollen legs lately. One month ago, she had a low-grade fever, a runny nose, painful joints, and a sore throat that resolved spontaneously. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She does not use illicit drugs. Medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 24-week gestation. There is bilateral edema around the ankles. Pelvic ultrasonography shows fluid accumulation within the fetal scalp and signs of pleural effusions bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections are asymptomatic in the majority of immunocompetent adults, although fever, malaise, and a sore throat (CMV mononucleosis) may occur. Fetal infections, on the other hand, can cause CNS abnormalities, hearing loss, and chorioretinitis. The infection can be diagnosed antenatally on ultrasound, which shows oligohydramnios or polyhydramnios, growth restriction, periventricular calcifications, and hydrops fetalis. While the mother could have an asymptomatic CMV infection, the absence of fetal periventricular calcifications on ultrasound rules out this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

A common feature of all diseases caused by herpes simplex viruses (HSV; e.g., labial and genital herpes, herpetic gingivostomatitis) is the development of painful blisters and ulcerations, which are not present in this patient. Furthermore, intrauterine HSV infections do not cause hydrops fetalis, but lead to microcephalus, hydrocephalus, microphthalmia, vesicular skin lesions, and very low birth weight.

C) CORRECT:

Parvovirus B19 infection, also known as erythema infectiosum, manifests with mild, cold-like symptoms and an exanthem that starts on the face (slapped-cheek rash) and spreads to the body. The characteristic rash is uncommon in adults, but they often develop associated symmetrical, polyarticular arthritis. Although most cases of congenital parvovirus B19 infection take a benign course, rare complications include fetal developmental defects, severe anemia, nonimmune fetal hydrops, and miscarriage or stillbirth.

See “Overview of congenital TORCH infections” table.

D) INCORRECT:

The varicella zoster virus (VZV) is the cause of chickenpox, a highly contagious disease characterized by fever, malaise, and a severely pruritic, widespread rash. Congenital varicella infections do not cause hydrops fetalis, but manifest with scar-like skin lesions, ocular symptoms (e.g., chorioretinitis) at birth, and limb hypoplasia and cortical atrophy, which are both detectable on antenatal ultrasound.

E) INCORRECT:

Listeria monocytogenes causes listeriosis, which is usually asymptomatic in adults but may manifest with fever, headache, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Although congenital listeriosis manifests at birth and cannot be diagnosed antenatally, the absence of symptoms in the mother rules out this diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

The rubella virus causes German measles, an infection characterized by a prodromal phase of flu-like symptoms and post-auricular lymphadenopathy, followed by a nonconfluent, pink maculopapular rash. Transplacental infection of the fetus occurs primarily in the first trimester and causes congenital rubella syndrome, which is characterized by a classic triad of cataracts, cochlear defects, and heart defects. Although rubella infections can also cause hydrops fetalis, infections > 20 weeks' gestation are rare.

G) INCORRECT:

Treponema pallidum is a bacteria that causes syphilis, which in adults usually manifests with a primary genital lesion (chancre), followed by constitutional symptoms (e.g., lymphadenopathy, fever), skin lesions (e.g., condylomata lata), and ultimately neurosyphilis. While congenital syphilis cannot be diagnosed antenatally and does not manifest until several months after birth, the absence of symptoms in the mother excludes this diagnosis.

H) INCORRECT:

Toxoplasma gondii causes toxoplasmosis, a disease that is usually asymptomatic in adults but can manifest with a sore throat, bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, and fever. Congenital toxoplasmosis, especially if contracted during the first trimester, may manifest with a typical clinical triad of chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications, and hydrocephalus. While this patient's presentation has some similarities with maternal toxoplasmosis, the absence of intracranial calcifications and hydrocephalus on antenatal ultrasound make this diagnosis unlikely.
questions.hint: This fetus has fluid accumulation within two fetal compartments (scalp and pleura), which suggests hydrops fetalis.

questions.text: A 3000-g (6.6-lb) female newborn is delivered at term to a 23-year-old primigravid woman. The mother has had no prenatal care. Immunization records are not available. Cardiac examination shows a continuous heart murmur. There are several bluish macules on the skin that do not blanch with pressure. Slit lamp examination shows cloudy lenses in both eyes. The newborn does not pass auditory screening tests. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Congenital parvovirus B19 infections can cause fetal hydrops and aplastic anemia, which can result in miscarriage. This newborn may have anemia, but she does not display signs of hydrops, such as edema of the subcutaneous tissue or scalp, ascites, or pleural effusions. Also, congenital parvovirus B19 infection does not cause cataracts, auditory defects, or a continuous heart murmur.

B) INCORRECT:

Newborns with congenital toxoplasmosis typically have chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications, and hydrocephalus, none of which are seen in this patient. Bilateral cataracts, auditory defects, and heart murmurs are not typical features of intrauterine infection with toxoplasmosis.

C) CORRECT:

The classic triad of congenital rubella infection is bilateral cataracts, sensorineural hearing loss (secondary to a cochlear dysfunction), and a heart defect – typically patent ductus arteriosus or pulmonary artery stenosis. Other, less specific findings include petechiae and purpura (blueberry muffin rash). Congenital rubella syndrome usually only results if the infection occurs during organogenesis (i.e., during the first 1–8 weeks of gestation). If the transmission occurs after 16 weeks' gestation, the risk of developing congenital rubella syndrome is extremely low. This infection could have been prevented with appropriate vaccination prior to pregnancy.

See “Overview of congenital TORCH infections” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Congenital cytomegalovirus infections typically manifest with sensorineural hearing loss, chorioretinitis, periventricular calcifications, and microcephaly. A congenital cytomegalovirus infection could cause an auditory defect and blueberry muffin rash, but it does not cause bilateral cataracts or a heart murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

Though congenital syphilis can cause sensorineural hearing loss, this is typically a late finding that does not occur until children have reached 8–10 years of age. Findings of early congenital syphilis include rhinorrhea with a white or bloody nasal discharge, a maculopapular rash on palms and soles, skeletal abnormalities (e.g., saber shins, saddle nose), dental abnormalities (e.g., notched teeth, mulberry molars), and nontender generalized lymphadenopathy, none of which are seen in this patient.
questions.hint: The newborn presents with cataracts, auditory defects, and a murmur suggestive of patent ductus arteriosus, which is a triad of symptoms characteristic of a particular congenital infection. In adults, this infection typically presents with flu-like symptoms and polyarthralgia.

questions.text: A 6-day-old female infant is brought to the emergency department because of poor feeding and irritability for two days. She was born at 39 weeks' gestation, and the pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. Her temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F). She appears lethargic and makes occasional twitching movements in both upper extremities. The anterior fontanelle is soft and full. A lumbar puncture is performed and analysis of the cerebrospinal fluid shows increased protein and decreased glucose. Cerebrospinal fluid culture shows gram-positive, intracellular rods with tumbling motility. Infection of a healthy adult with the pathogen affecting this infant would most likely present with which of the following clinical conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is the most common pathogen implicated in cystitis. E. coli can cause neonatal meningitis, as seen in this patient. However, E. coli is a gram-negative rather than a gram-positive rod, and, therefore, is not the pathogen responsible for this patient's condition. Listeria monocytogenes is not typically known to cause cystitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most commonly implicated pathogen for pneumonia in healthy adults. Although it is a common pathogen responsible for meningitis in infants (1 month to 2 years), it is uncommon in neonates. Listeria monocytogenes is not a common cause of pneumonia in healthy adults.

C) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae are the most common bacteria responsible for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) in adolescents and adults. Although these bacteria can cause neonatal infections, these typically manifest with conjunctivitis and not with the meningitis seen in this patient. Listeria monocytogenes is not known to cause PID.

D) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitidis are the most commonly implicated bacterial pathogens in meningitis in healthy adults. Although these are also the most common pathogens responsible for meningitis in infants (1 month to 2 years), they are uncommon in neonates. Listeria monocytogenes, the pathogen responsible for this patient's presentation, can cause meningitis in adults; however, it typically only affects older adults (> 60 years) or immunocompromised individuals. Another condition is more likely in a healthy adult with L. monocytogenes.

E) CORRECT:

Listeria monocytogenes most commonly causes self-limited gastroenteritis in healthy adults. It classically is accompanied by a history of dairy product or deli meat consumption (it grows well at refrigeration temperatures). Although typically a self-limiting condition in healthy adults, Listeria infection is more concerning in infants, older adults, and those with compromised immune systems. These high-risk individuals should be treated with ampicillin.
questions.hint: This baby has signs and symptoms of meningitis. Gram-positive intracellular rods with tumbling motility is suggestive of infection with Listeria monocytogenes.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents several weeks after the family immigrated from Russia. The parents are worried because the child appears to have trouble seeing and has not started walking. The child was born at home and has never been evaluated by a physician. During the pregnancy, the mother had a week of fever, myalgia, diffuse rash, and bilateral nontender cervical adenopathy after the family adopted a cat. The patient is lethargic and irritable when aroused. Vital signs are within normal limits. The eyes deviate inferiorly and the eyelids are retracted. Ophthalmologic examination shows inflammation of the choroid and the retina in both eyes. An MRI of the head is shown. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Maculopapular rash on palms and soles
Tuft of hair over the lumbosacral area
Loss of pain sensation in the cervicothoracic dermatomes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A continuous machinery murmur arises from a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). PDA is associated with congenital rubella infection but is not seen in congenital toxoplasmosis infection. While congenital rubella can also cause vision abnormalities (e.g., due to cataracts), it is not usually associated with hydrocephalus.

B) INCORRECT:

A maculopapular rash on the palms and soles is characteristic of congenital syphilis, which should be considered in children born to mothers who did not receive prenatal care. Congenital syphilis can manifest with hydrocephalus, but this child does not present with other findings consistent with this condition (e.g., hepatomegaly and jaundice, Hutchinson teeth, mulberry molars, facial or skeletal alterations, generalized lymphadenopathy). In addition, this patient's mother does not have a history compatible with syphilis.

C) CORRECT:

Signs of upper motor neuron damage (e.g., spasticity, hyperreflexia) are common in advanced, chronic hydrocephalus due to stretching of the motor cortices and pyramidal tracts around the dilated ventricles. The lower extremities are typically affected because the cortical regions responsible for processing the motor functions of the lower extremities are located in the medial precentral gyrus (according to the motor homunculus), which is the most stretched part of the primary motor cortex in patients with hydrocephalus. Other symptoms of hydrocephalus in children include difficulty feeding, irritability, and macrocephaly.

Another classic finding in congenital toxoplasmosis is diffuse intracranial calcifications. Pregnant women should avoid raw meats and contact with cat litter to prevent toxoplasmosis.

D) INCORRECT:

A tuft of hair in the lumbosacral region is associated with spina bifida occulta. More severe forms of spina bifida can be associated with myelomeningocele, which itself is associated with hydrocephalus. However, patients with myelomeningoceles have a gross deformity of the lumbosacral area, not relatively minor findings such as a tuft of hair. Spina bifida occulta is not usually associated with hydrocephalus.

E) INCORRECT:

Loss of pain sensation in the cervicothoracic dermatomes (i.e., in a shawl distribution) is consistent with syringomyelia. The development of a syrinx in the center of the cervical spinal cord progressively compresses neurons of the spinothalamic tract, which explains the loss of pain (and typically temperature) sensation in the upper extremities. Later findings can include weakness or even paralysis as alpha motor neurons become compromised. Hydrocephalus is not associated with this finding.
questions.hint: This patient likely developed congenital toxoplasmosis after his mother had a primary infection (fever, myalgia, and nontender cervical adenopathy following exposure to an infected cat). Cardinal manifestations of congenital toxoplasmosis include chorioretinitis and hydrocephalus.

questions.text: An investigator studying patients with symptoms of arthritis detects a nonenveloped virus with a single-stranded DNA genome in the serum of a pregnant patient. Fetal infection with this pathogen is most likely to cause which of the following manifestations?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Parvovirus B19, a congenital TORCH infection, can lead to the development of hydrops fetalis during pregnancy. Infection of RBCs by this virus induces apoptosis and massive destruction of erythroid lineage cells, causing severe anemia and heart failure in the fetus (secondary to excessive fluid accumulation within the fetal vascular compartments). This often fatal condition can also be caused by chromosomal abnormalities, inborn errors of metabolism, Rh incompatibility, lymphatic dysplasia, and Treponema pallidum infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Chorioretinitis in a fetus is often due to an infection with Toxoplasma gondii or cytomegalovirus (CMV). These intrauterine infections are also associated with hydrocephalus and intracranial calcifications (periventricular with CMV). However, T. gondii is a protozoan, and CMV is an enveloped dsDNA virus, in contrast to the nonenveloped ssDNA virus being studied. Furthermore, neither of these infections are known to cause arthritis in adults.

C) INCORRECT:

Microcephaly in a fetus may be due to an infection with Zika virus (a Flavivirus). This intrauterine infection may also present with mild fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis. Although Zika virus can cause arthralgias in adults, it is an enveloped ssRNA virus, unlike the nonenveloped ssDNA virus identified by the investigator.

D) INCORRECT:

Notched, widely spaced teeth in a young child is a highly suggestive finding of a congenital infection with Treponema pallidum (a Spirochete). This infection may also present with sensorineural deafness, facial abnormalities (saddle nose, short maxilla), saber shins, and hydrops fetalis. T. pallidum is a bacterium, not a virus.

E) INCORRECT:

Sensorineural hearing loss in a fetus may be due to an infection with rubella virus, Treponema pallidum, or cytomegalovirus (CMV). While both rubella and T. pallidum (secondary syphilis) may cause arthritis in adult patients, rubella is an enveloped ssRNA virus, T. pallidum is a bacteria, and CMV is a dsDNA virus. Therefore, none of these infections fit the nonenveloped ssDNA virus profile identified by the investigator.

F) INCORRECT:

A vesicular rash in a fetus is highly suggestive of an intrauterine or perinatal infection with herpes simplex virus (typically HSV-2). This infection can lead to a variety of clinical features including fetal demise, microcephaly, and meningoencephalitis. The HSV-2 virus is an enveloped dsDNA virus, unlike the nonenveloped ssDNA virus identified by the investigator.
questions.hint: Parvovirus B19 is one of the few nonenveloped ssDNA viruses that infect humans. It can lead to transplacental fetal infection.

questions.text: Three days after delivery, a male newborn suddenly has a high-grade fever, seizures, and hypotonia. He was delivered at 35 weeks' gestation to a 26-year-old woman following a pregnancy complicated by maternal fever and chorioamnionitis during the third trimester. Apgar scores were 6 and 6 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. His mother received no prenatal care. His temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 180/min, respirations are 80/min, and blood pressure is 70/45 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination discloses grunting breath sounds. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. There is hepatomegaly. Cerebral ultrasound shows diffuse hyperechogenicity. Which of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for this newborn's condition?

choices.text: Transvaginal transmission of herpes simplex virus
Maternal contact with cat feces during pregnancy
Maternal consumption of unpasteurized cheese during pregnancy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Congenital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection can manifest with signs of CNS disease (e.g., fever, seizures, hypotonia, abnormal brain ultrasound) and sepsis-like disseminated disease (e.g., hepatomegaly, pneumonitis). However, transvaginal transmission mostly occurs in mothers with genital herpes; chorioamnionitis and PPROM are not typical of maternal HSV infection. Infected infants usually also have characteristic diffuse vesicular skin lesions and may develop keratoconjunctivitis. Finally, CNS disease generally manifests in the second or third week of life rather than 3 days after birth.

B) INCORRECT:

Maternal contact with cat feces during pregnancy is a risk factor for toxoplasmosis. Congenital toxoplasmosis may cause premature birth and manifest with fever, seizures, pneumonitis, and hepatomegaly. However, infected mothers are usually asymptomatic or develop a mononucleosis-like disease during pregnancy; chorioamnionitis and PPROM are not typical. The severity of congenital disease decreases with gestational age: while first-trimester infection usually results in a classic triad (chorioretinitis, diffuse intracranial calcifications, hydrocephalus) and other nonspecific features (e.g., blueberry muffin rash, jaundice, macrocephaly), second- or third-trimester infections are mostly subclinical or mild. This patient's severe neonatal sepsis with meningoencephalitis is better explained by a different condition.

C) CORRECT:

Consumption of unpasteurized milk products is a risk factor for listeriosis, which typically manifests with self-limiting gastroenteritis in healthy adults. In pregnant women, however, listeriosis can cause complications (e.g., fever, chorioamnionitis, PPROM) and result in preterm birth or spontaneous abortion. Transmission from an infected mother to the fetus can either occur transplacentally or via direct contact with infected vaginal secretions and/or blood during delivery. This patient likely has early-onset neonatal listeriosis (granulomatosis infantiseptica), manifesting with severe systemic infection and disseminated organ involvement (i.e., of the liver and lungs). Signs of meningitis (e.g., fever, seizures, hypotonia, abnormal cerebral ultrasound) may develop as early as seen here, especially in preterm neonates, or have a delayed onset in the 3 weeks after birth, typically in full-term neonates with perinatal infection. Both mother and newborn should be treated with IV ampicillin and gentamicin.

D) INCORRECT:

Transplacental transmission of Treponema pallidum causes congenital syphilis, which may manifest with hepatomegaly and, in rare cases, neurological symptoms (e.g., seizures, hypotonia), fever, and sepsis. However, this patient's mother reports no features of present or past syphilis. Moreover, while fetal syphilis may result in miscarriage, stillbirth, or hydrops fetalis, chorioamnionitis or PPROM are not typical. The majority of newborns with congenital syphilis are asymptomatic at birth; symptoms of early congenital syphilis (e.g., jaundice, rhinorrhea, maculopapular rash on the palms and soles, skeletal abnormalities, lymphadenopathy) and, rarely, syphilitic leptomeningitis develop over several months. This newborn's acute septic meningoencephalitis is better explained by a different condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Preterm newborns like this patient are particularly susceptible to postnatal transmission of cytomegalovirus (CMV; e.g., through breast milk from an infected mother), and neonatal CMV infection can manifest with fever, seizures, hypotonia, hepatomegaly, pneumonitis, and sepsis. However, CMV infection during pregnancy generally manifests with nonspecific flu-like symptoms rather than chorioamnionitis and PPROM, and transmission is primarily transplacental. At birth, 90% of infected infants are asymptomatic, and those that develop symptoms often also present with a blueberry muffin rash, jaundice, small size for gestational age, microcephaly, and sensorineural hearing loss. Neuroimaging characteristically shows periventricular calcifications and hydrocephalus rather than diffuse hyperechogenicity.
questions.hint: This newborn has a high-grade fever, respiratory distress, and hepatomegaly, indicating neonatal sepsis. In addition, the seizures, hypotonia, and abnormal cerebral ultrasound suggest meningoencephalitis. Maternal infection, as evidenced by chorioamnionitis and premature rupture of membranes (PPROM), is a typical source of early-onset disease (before 5 days of life) in preterm infants.

questions.text: A 1-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 1-week history of increased fussiness and a rash. Initially, the rash was bright and copper-red but gradually started to fade and peel off. The patient has been feeding poorly and has not gained much weight since birth. His mother notes that he also has had a “runny nose” for the past 2 weeks. She received no prenatal care. The patient was born at 39 weeks' gestation following an uncomplicated pregnancy and spontaneous delivery at home. His birth weight was 2900-g (6.4-Ib). His older brother had chickenpox 2 weeks ago but the patient has not had any sick contacts otherwise. He cries but calms when his mother picks him up. He is at the 3rd percentile for length and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows diffuse erythematous plaques on the soles and buttocks with desquamation. There is nasal congestion and a white nasal discharge. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Blood culture can be used to diagnose granulomatosis infantiseptica, which can also manifest with irritability, poor feeding, and skin lesions in an infant. However, patients typically present with diffuse papular or ulcerative lesions rather than erythematous plaques on the buttocks and soles. Moreover, granulomatosis infantiseptica typically manifests at birth or shortly after with sepsis, respiratory distress, and possibly signs of meningitis. Lastly, white nasal discharge and hepatomegaly are not characteristic of this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

A PCR assay of the nose and throat swab can be used to confirm the diagnosis of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD), which can also manifest with a rash, irritability, and poor feeding in an infant. While the rash associated with coxsackie A virus can occur on the soles of the feet and buttocks, it is usually maculopapular and/or vesicular and involves the hands. In addition, most patients with HFMD develop fever and oral ulcers. Lastly, white nasal discharge and hepatomegaly are not characteristic of HFMD.
Image Description:

Soles of the feet of a child

Macular, vesicular lesions on an erythematous base are visible on the toes and the soles of the feet.

This rash is typical in hand, foot, and mouth disease.

C) INCORRECT:

A Gram stain of a skin lesion swab can be used for the diagnosis of bacterial skin infections such as staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) or impetigo, both of which can manifest with a rash, irritability, and poor feeding in an infant. However, bacterial skin infections typically manifest with vesicular, pustular, or bullous lesions rather than erythematous plaques. While the desquamation of skin lesions is typical for SSSS, the initial manifestation of this condition is rapidly progressive, widespread cutaneous erythema with large easily ruptured blisters. In addition, hepatomegaly and white nasal discharge are not characteristic of bacterial skin infections.
Image Description:

There is diffuse erythema of all visible skin. Large ruptured blisters are visible on the left lower leg, and a large flaccid unruptured blister can be seen on the left buttock.

D) CORRECT:

This infant presents with features that suggest early congenital syphilis (maculopapular rash on the soles and buttocks with desquamation, failure to thrive, white nasal discharge, hepatomegaly), for which a nontreponemal assay such as a Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) test is the best initial diagnostic option. The direct visualization of Treponema pallidum in nasal discharge on darkfield microscopy confirms the diagnosis. Congenital syphilis is most common in children born to mothers who have not received prenatal care and/or were inadequately treated for syphilis before or during pregnancy. Further evaluation of affected infants includes CBC, CSF analysis, HIV testing, and other tests depending on the clinical presentation (e.g., long-bone x-ray for skeletal abnormalities, liver function tests for hepatomegaly). Treatment consists of a 10-day course of IV penicillin G.

Syphilis screening is a mandatory part of the first prenatal visit in most US states.

E) INCORRECT:

A Tzanck test is most commonly used for the rapid diagnosis of varicella-zoster virus (VZV) and herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections when the clinical diagnosis is equivocal. This infant's contact with a person infected with VZV puts him at risk for chickenpox, which typically manifests two weeks after exposure. However, the varicella rash is widespread, usually severely pruritic, starts on the trunk, before spreading to the face, scalp, and extremities, and most patients present with rash in different stages of development (e.g., erythematous macules, vesicles filled with clear fluid, crusted papules). Neonatal HSV infection can manifest with skin lesions; however, the lesions are typically vesicular and associated with ocular (e.g., excessive tearing) and oropharyngeal (e.g., oral ulcerations) symptoms. Hepatomegaly, white nasal discharge, and erythematous plaques with desquamation on the buttocks and soles are not expected in either of these conditions.
Image Description:

The face of the girl shows macules, vesicles, and papules on an erythematous base, as well as erupted vesicles and crusted papules. The simultaneous occurrence of various stages of rash is sometimes described as "starry sky" and is typical of chickenpox.
questions.hint: Receiving prenatal care would most likely have prevented this infant's condition.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman who is 32 weeks pregnant is hospitalized with 2 days of fever and myalgias. She states that she has not experienced headache, stiff neck, or photophobia, and she has a normal neurologic examination. She has received normal prenatal care and has no significant medical history, with the exception of an allergy to sulfonamide antibiotics. She reports that her family recently had a picnic where Mexican-style cheese was served and that several of her family members subsequently became ill with diarrhea.
Blood cultures grew gram-positive rods in both the aerobic and anaerobic bottles after 12 hours of incubation.
Which one of the following antibiotics is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin has been used to treat Listeria infection, but treatment failures and, rarely, resistance have been reported.

B) INCORRECT:

Tetracyclines are not recommended for treatment of Listeria infection, in part because of uncertain clinical efficacy and bacteriostatic, rather than bacteriocidal, activity in vitro; in addition, tetracycline should not be administered during pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Cephalosporins, such as ceftriaxone, are not active against Listeria.

D) CORRECT:

Listeriosis, a food-borne disease typically caused by the gram-positive rod Listeria monocytogenes, can manifest as a self-limited febrile gastroenteritis or as invasive disease in pregnant women and immunocompromised individuals. Multiple food vehicles have been associated with outbreaks, including deli meats and Mexican-style cheese. Intravenous ampicillin is the treatment of choice for Listeria; the specific treatment regimen and duration should be determined in consultation with an infectious diseases specialist.

Key learning point: The most appropriate antibiotic for treating invasive listeriosis is ampicillin.

E) INCORRECT:

In penicillin-allergic patients, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is a useful second-line agent; however, it should not be given to a patient with a history of an allergy to sulfonamide antibiotics.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old gravida 2, para 1 woman at 39 weeks’ gestation presents with painful contractions every 2 minutes for the past 5 hours. She has had an uncomplicated pregnancy and has no known medical problems. On cervical examination, she is 5 cm dilated. Tocometry confirms regular uterine contractions.
An ulcerative rash is visible around the anus and vulva (figure). The patient reports that she felt a burning sensation at that location 2 days ago. She has no known history of sexually transmitted infections and has never noted a similar genital rash. She reports no change in vaginal discharge.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate intravenous acyclovir, and proceed with vaginal delivery
Initiate therapy with intravenous fluconazole, and proceed with vaginal delivery
Place an occlusive dressing on the lesions, and proceed with vaginal delivery
Swab the lesions to send for bacterial, fungal, and viral cultures

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous acyclovir is a reasonable option for therapy, given that high intraamniotic levels are attained with intravenous dosing. Acyclovir has not been shown to lower the rate of perinatal transmission; although it may be used in addition to cesarean section in some patients, its use is secondary to a cesarean delivery.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole is used to treat fungal infections. The appearance of these skin lesions is not consistent with fungal or bacterial vaginitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Viral shedding can occur in areas of genital skin that appear normal, so an occlusive dressing may not prevent transmission in this patient. For patients with active nongenital herpes lesions (including on the thigh, back, and buttock), appropriate management would involve covering the lesions with an occlusive dressing and delivering vaginally.

D) INCORRECT:

Viral culture results are unlikely to be available in time to affect management, given that this patient is already in active labor.

E) CORRECT:

Clumps of vesicular lesions on an erythematous base are present around the patient's anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving shallow ulcerations. These features are most consistent with genital herpes.

Herpes infection is a cause of significant infant morbidity and mortality. Cesarean delivery has been shown to reduce this risk and is the standard of care for pregnant women with an active outbreak of genital herpes.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management approach for a pregnant woman with an active outbreak of genital herpes at the onset of labor is cesarean section.

questions.text:
A 9-day-old male infant is brought into the emergency department for evaluation of a rash that his parents noticed last night. He was born at full term via spontaneous uncomplicated vaginal delivery 20 hours after rupture of membranes. His mother, a 26-year-old primiparous woman, had an uncomplicated pregnancy, took appropriate prenatal vitamins, and had normal prenatal laboratory findings. The infant has been breastfeeding well since discharge from the hospital 7 days ago and is now 1% below his birth weight.
His temperature, measured rectally, is 37.2°C. On examination, he is alert and in no distress. A group of clustered vesicles is noted on his scalp and forehead (figure). The rest of his physical examination is unremarkable.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Obtain a Wright stain of the forehead lesions to confirm eosinophils
Obtain viral culture of the forehead lesions and mucous membranes, as well as polymerase chain-reaction testing of cerebrospinal fluid for herpes simplex virus, and initiate intravenous acyclovir
Obtain bacterial and viral cultures of the forehead lesions, and initiate oral acyclovir
Obtain Gram stain and culture of the forehead lesions, and initiate topical antibacterial ointment
Obtain viral and bacterial blood cultures, and initiate intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wright staining is used to distinguish between blood-cell types and can reveal eosinophils when taken from the neonatal pustular rash of erythema toxicum. Wright staining does not have a role in the workup for suspected viral infections.

B) CORRECT:

Any neonate with a vesicular rash should be evaluated and treated for possible infection with herpes simplex virus (HSV). The index of suspicion for such infection should be high, given the potential for progression to severe morbidity and death. Empiric acyclovir (20 mg/kg every 8 hours) should be administered intravenously while confirmatory laboratory results are pending. Oral acyclovir is not appropriate.

Most cases of neonatal HSV transmission occur during delivery, and often the mother has no known history or symptoms of HSV infection. Neonatal HSV infections are classified into three categories based on clinical manifestations:
• Isolated skin, eye, and mouth (SEM) disease, which accounts for 45% of cases and can progress to central nervous system (CNS) infection or disseminated disease if left untreated.
• CNS disease, which accounts for 30% of cases and is characterized by lethargy, poor feeding, and seizures with or without cutaneous lesions
• Disseminated disease, which accounts for 25% of cases, is clinically indistinguishable from bacterial sepsis, and frequently involves the liver

Isolated eye disease can also occur, and HSV infection should be in the differential diagnosis for infants presenting with a swollen and inflamed eye.

This patient's vesicular rash in the absence of symptoms of sepsis or neurologic signs is most suggestive of HSV SEM disease, but CNS infection must be ruled out with a lumbar puncture. Laboratory studies should include HSV polymerase chain-reaction (PCR) testing and viral culture of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), as well as of the skin lesions and mucous membranes (conjunctivae, mouth, nasopharynx, and rectum). HSV PCR testing of the blood is also recommended. When there is a consideration for perinatally acquired HSV infection, intravenous acyclovir should be initiated pending results of the microbiologic workup. Only intravenous acyclovir (not oral) is appropriate in these cases, given the unpredictable bioavailability of acyclovir in young infants.

Key learning point: Any neonate with a vesicular rash should be evaluated for herpes simplex virus infection and have acyclovir initiated empirically while the microbiologic investigation is pending.

C) INCORRECT:

Empiric acyclovir should be administered intravenously while confirmatory laboratory results are pending. Oral acyclovir is not appropriate because of its unpredictable bioavailability in young infants.

D) INCORRECT:

Gram staining is used to distinguish between gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria but is not helpful in diagnosing a viral infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Given that this patient shows no signs of bacterial or viral sepsis, bacterial and viral blood cultures are not the best next step in evaluation, and there is no indication for antibacterial therapy.

questions.text:
A 2-hour-old newborn girl of unknown gestational age is transferred to the neonatal intensive care unit with a concerning rash. She was born via uncomplicated vaginal delivery to a 23-year-old gravida 1, para 1 mother who is a refugee and was unable to seek prenatal care. The infant weighs 2117 grams, and her Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at one and five minutes, respectively.
On examination, the neonate is afebrile, without respiratory distress, and with pre- and postductal oxygen saturations above 95%. She has numerous violaceous purpuric lesions spread diffusely throughout her face; they measure approximately 2 to 5 mm each and do not blanch with pressure. Similar lesions are noted on her neck, torso, and extremities, without pustules or vesicles, and there are also a few scattered petechiae (figure).
On eye examination, red reflexes are not detectable, and a cloudy gray object is visualized just beyond the pupils bilaterally.
A continuous machinelike murmur is heard at the upper left sternal border.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
17,500
9000–30,000


Neutrophils (%)
65
66–87


Lymphocytes (%)
20
22–37


Monocytes (%)
15
4–11


Platelet count (per mm3)
25,000
150,000–450,000


Hemoglobin
13.2
13.5–19.5


Hematocrit (%)
36
42–60


Blood cultures are collected, and empiric antibiotics are initiated.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most likely to reveal this patient’s underlying condition?

choices.text: Maternal testing for anti-Ro (SSA) and anti-La (SSB) antibodies
Serum testing for HIV-1 and -2 antibodies

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neonatal lupus can manifest with a red annular rash during the newborn period. Affected infants may present with heart block but do not classically have a murmur. Some may have thrombocytopenia. Diagnostic testing would include measurement of anti-Ro (SSA) and anti-La (SSB) antibodies in the mother.

B) INCORRECT:

The symptoms of congenital CMV infection can overlap with those of congenital rubella and other congenital infections (e.g., toxoplasmosis), but CMV infection typically manifests with microcephaly, thrombocytopenia, hepatitis, sensorineural hearing loss, and intracranial calcifications. When congenital CMV infection is being considered in an infant, the diagnostic test of choice includes CMV PCR testing from urine, saliva, or both, as serum CMV-specific antibodies (IgG/IgM) may represent maternal immunoglobulins.

C) CORRECT:

The combination of rash, cataracts, and congenital heart disease in this infant is concerning for congenital rubella syndrome (CRS), a constellation of symptoms that results from in utero infection with rubella virus.

The risk of an infant acquiring rubella — and the specific clinical manifestations of CRS — depends in part on the timing of maternal infection. The risk for maternal-fetal transmission of rubella virus is highest when maternal infection occurs before the 10th week of gestation. Rubella virus can affect any organ system in a developing fetus, and infants who are infected during the first trimester are the most likely to have congenital anomalies and multisystem involvement, including:

• Cardiac anomalies (patent ductus arteriosus, peripheral pulmonary stenosis)
• Eye disease (cataracts, microphthalmos, glaucoma)
• Neurologic outcomes (microcephaly, sensorineural hearing loss)

These end-organ defects are thought to stem from direct cytopathic damage to tissues during infection; thus, infants who are infected with rubella later during pregnancy, after organogenesis, generally do not present with this constellation of findings. Congenital defects are not typically seen when maternal infection occurs beyond 20 weeks’ gestation.

Infants with CRS often have low birth weight and can present with petechiae and purpura, also known as a blueberry muffin rash.

Diagnosis of CRS requires the presence of at least one associated clinical finding, plus laboratory confirmation of rubella infection, as demonstrated by any of the following:

• Rubella-specific immunoglobulin M (IgM)
• Rubella-specific immunoglobulin G (IgG)
• Isolation of rubella virus
• Positive polymerase chain-reaction (PCR) testing for rubella virus

A positive test for rubella-specific IgG alone in the immediate postnatal period may reflect maternal antibody and not necessarily neonatal infection. If used for diagnostic evaluation, rubella-specific IgG levels should be monitored over time; levels that increase or persist beyond 7 months (when maternal antibody levels would be expected to decline and eventually resolve) would signal infection of the infant.

Ruling out infection is important in infants whose mothers did not receive prenatal care and thus did not undergo routine screening. All such infants should be tested for HIV, syphilis, and hepatitis B virus (which are included in standard prenatal testing in the United States); those who present with symptoms of infection should undergo additional testing. Although CRS is the most likely diagnosis in this case, other congenital infections to consider, given the presenting signs and symptoms, include toxoplasmosis, Zika, varicella, and cytomegalovirus (CMV).
